resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: A secutor ( "the follower" in Latin) was specially trained to fight the retiarius, a type of lightly armoured gladiator. A secutor was fighting with a short sword (gladius) and he was protected by a heavy shield (scutum), a helmet, an arm guard (manica) and greaves (ochrea).
resource.chars: A secutor ( "the follower" in Latin) was specially trained to fight the retiarius, a type of lightly armoured gladiator. A secutor was fighting with a short sword (gladius) and he was protected by a heavy shield (scutum), a helmet, an arm guard (manica) and greaves (ochrea).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The rudis (the "referee" in Latin) managed the fight and enforced the rules. He wore a tunic and a stick (rudis) to be able to intervene. The fights were not necessarily to the death and the referee had to stop the fight when a gladiator gave up.
resource.chars: The rudis (the "referee" in Latin) managed the fight and enforced the rules. He wore a tunic and a stick (rudis) to be able to intervene. The fights were not necessarily to the death and the referee had to stop the fight when a gladiator gave up.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: A retiarius ("net-man" in Latin) was a gladiator who fought with equipment styled on that of a fisherman: a weighted net and a three-pointed trident. He was lightly armoured, wearing an arm guard (manica) and a shoulder guard (galerus).
resource.chars: A retiarius ("net-man" in Latin) was a gladiator who fought with equipment styled on that of a fisherman: a weighted net and a three-pointed trident. He was lightly armoured, wearing an arm guard (manica) and a shoulder guard (galerus).
